results.title: Little white lies
results.brief_description: Coming out is hard to do - but is procrastinating any easier? Reb finds that when you’ve got a secret and they’ve got your number, a little white lie can sometimes do wonders - but not always. Cast features Joy Smithers and Sylvia Mircevsky.

results.title: Zoo baby animals
results.creator_credit: John Walker and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Opportunity for children to look behind the scenes at the zoo - to see activities in the kitchen and hospital; how baby animals are fed and cared for by their keepers. Shows many animals in attractive outdoor settings and in “children’s zoo” sections in the famous Lincoln Park and Brookfield Zoos of Chicago. Baby animals featured in the film are the lion, tiger, gorilla, bear, elephant, harbor seal, kudu, llama, Barbary sheep, tapir and baboon.

results.title: Zoo
results.creator_credit: Gerry Hudson, David Hughes, Ross Campbell and Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre
results.brief_description: This film was made at the Melbourne Zoo and, without commentary, shows the activities - particularly eating - of birds in the air and animals on land and in water. There are some interesting close-ups of parts of animals, eg. the texture of the skin of a hippo and the back of an eagle.

results.title: Zoo
results.creator_credit: Gerry Hudson, Ross Campbell and Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre
results.brief_description: This film explores a wide variety of animals on display at the Melbourne Zoo. All the major different animal groups are represented and each animal is shown in a natural environment. Gives a close look to animals we would not normally see at close range.

results.title: The Traditional world of Islam: nomad and city
results.brief_description: The nomads and the city dwellers - these are the two roles of Islamic civilization, and it is the tension existing between the two which has given to it an inner energy and capacity for self-renewal.

results.title: The Track
results.creator_credit: Michael Cordell, Nick Greenaway, Victoria Pitt, Penny Chapman, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Chapman Pictures and Hilton Cordell Productions
results.brief_description: A 6 part series on the history of the Australian Racing Industry from the different points of view of the jockeys, trainers, bookies, callers, punters and politicians. Horse racing started in the 1700’s to give the developing colony something social and sporting to go to, and was a popular pastime, despite the ban on swearing, fighting, gambling and drinking, and has since developed into a huge industry. Each episode covers a period of time in racing history from 1788 to current racing, and includes interviews with trainers, jockeys and callers of the past. Footage of famous horses includes Phar Lap and Bernborough. Narrated by Tiriel Mora.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Cordell, Nick Greenaway, Victoria Pitt, Penny Chapman, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Chapman Pictures and Hilton Cordell Productions

results.title: Vision in mathematics: linear programming
results.brief_description: Examines ideas leading to consideration of linear programming, such as the values of various combinations of coins. Also shows the sequence of operations in preparing a linear program for the computer.

results.title: Visages de femmes = Faces of women
results.creator_credit: Desire Ecare and Films de la Lagune
results.brief_description: Twelve years in the making, “Visages de Femmes” is a wonderfully unpredictable and creative look at the financial, sexual and emotional emancipation of African women. The film is a series of episodes linked by a chorus featuring traditional singing and dancing. Ecare’s achievement is to create a visual feast which owes little to colonial models of cinema.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Desire Ecare and Films de la Lagune

results.title: Vintage: A History of Wine. Eps. 7 & 8
results.creator_credit: Christopher Ralling, Michael Gill, Channel Four, Malone Gill Productions and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description: Sipping stars recounts the history of champagne, from its invention by Dom Perignon during the reign of Louis XIV, the addition of the bubbles by the British during the reign of Charles II and the introduction of mass production methods by La Veuve Clicquot which led to its international success. “Wine and war” shows how the sweet fortified wines, particularly Madeira and Port were embraced by the British and Americans when French and German wines became unobtainable during the Napoleonic wars.
